name: Sophie AOSE
comment info: In this graph, it depicts how the temperatures between the months of January and December have changed from 1850 to 2023. Generally, I noticed that as the years progress, the temperatures drastically rise. For example, in the 1940s-60s, the highest temperature between January and December was around +0.7 degrees celsius, whereas the highest temperature in 2023 was above +1.6 degrees. Each decade, the temperatures become further and further away from the average temperature of below 0 in 1850-1900. I wonder what the main cause of this rise in temperatures is and think that it may be due to climate change because greenhouse gas emissions lead to global warming. Additionally, I noticed that the temperatures for most decades are typically the highest in January, except for the 1970s and 2020s, and I wonder what the cause of this is. Also, I noticed that there is usually a drop in temperature right near December and then it rises again. This applies to my community because I have experienced global warming first hand and it is something that is very concerning for the environment. My headline for this graph would be: “How Hot Can Global Temperatures Get?”.

name: Shifa Sayeed
comment info:
I noticed that throughout the decades, the climate of our world has only been climbing up. Despite the incredible technological advances we have seen in this decade, it looks like there has not been a stopping point for the severe increase in temperature. Additionally, I noticed how the graph depicts the heat in each decade in a different color, each decade's color becoming more red. This noticeable stylistic choice strikes me with fascination, making me ponder about the evident climate change we are witnessing.
Why hasn't there been a sense of stability in the climate already? Especially since when you look at the previous decades, the trend of the temperatures increasing has been an evident feature of today's world for a long time so it is strange that there hasn't been a sense of regulation established already. Furthermore, with the severity of the heat depicted in the 2020 decade, I wonder if the effects of that have become even more unavoidable and clear in comparison to the other decades.
Whether it is humans, animals or plants even, we are being strongly affected by the climb in climate. We have already seen the effects on air quality, endangerment of animals, and lack of snow days. If we continue our lives oblivious to the dangerous increase in temperature, this damage will be almost impossible to reverse. 
This Decade's Hot Topic

name: Sana Goyal
comment info:
I noticed that each subsequent decade has relatively increased in temperature with the hottest decade since 1940 being 2020. Additionally, I noticed that in general, the decades and years didn't keep the regular seasonal pattern; the winters weren't always shown to be colder than the summers. This is especially true for the 2023 line where the temperature actually peaked in December. This is probably because of the seasonal flip between the northern and southern hemispheres. 

I wonder how much of this increase in temperature is from human activity and how much is the earth naturally increasing in temperature. Most likely, this large growth is from the peaking industrialization of the world, leading to more fossil fuel consumption and increased greenhouse gas release. I also wonder what could happen in the future if this trend were to continue. Would we find a solution before the earth became completely uninhabitable or insupportable to our current way of life? 

This affects my community and the whole world because if temperatures keep rising, eventually life itself will need to make a major change or risk extinction. This problem is also not isolated to the distant future because, even if the world does not completely end due to the rise in temperature, it will see a substantial shift for the worse, for example, increasing natural disasters and worse air quality. 

Title: Can't Stop the Heat

name: Isabella P. AOSE
comment info:
This graph shows temperatures throughout the past few decades (1940s-2023). The trend is each decade, temperatures are rising. The average temperature for 1850-1900 has risen 1°C since then. Temperatures in the 20s have not been exceptionally high on a global scale. This may be due to COVID and the COVID recovery years (2021-2022) because it halted many modes of transportation and slowed the economy due to a reduction in manufacturing. These factors can play a role in reducing the temperatures of the world. As we know, fossil fuels produced from transportation and manufacturing are depleting the ozone layer and causing temperatures to rise (global warming). During COVID, studies showed that the ozone layer was healing itself as a result of less carbon emissions going into the air. In 2023, the world was back in full swing. The carbon emissions probably depleted every ounce the ozone layer supposedly healed during COVID following when the restrictions were lifted. In 2023 the ozone layer probably broke down even further resulting in a rise in temperatures. I wonder why temperatures were so high in 2016. This relates to me because it is the dead of winter in NJ and this Saturday is going to be 57° Fahrenheit! This is abnormally high for a winter day in the middle of February. I predict that in future years, temperatures will continue to rise. If we do not do something major to help reduce global warming soon there will be dire consequences. 
"2023 Record High, We Might Die"

name: Moderator Amy
comment info:
Thanks to all the students who responded.   Here are some of the catchy headlines that we received:  “It’s Only Getting Hotter: Climate Change Through the Decades” by Elizabeth of Mich.; “'How Hot Is Too Hot?” by Destii of Franklin Square N.Y.; “Are Rising Temperatures Becoming an Uphill Climb?” by Sylvia of Pewaukee High School in Wis. And four headlines from Andover High School in Massachusetts -- “The Steady Climb of Global Temperatures Visualized” by Bryce, “Planet on Fire: The Decades-Long Surge in Global Temperatures” by Jana, “Earth’s Fever: Global Temperatures Surge High In Past Century, Climate Catastrophe Looms” by Matt and “Spiking Temperatures: It's Only Up from Here.” by Owen.
 
Please return on Friday when we will reveal the free link to the article that includes this graph.  Also in the Reveal are a summary of the topic, additional questions, shout outs for some of the best headlines for the graph and Stat Nuggets -- definitions of words that relate to the graph and where you can find them in the graph.
 
The next graph will be released by Friday, February 9.  Live-moderation will be on Wednesday, February 14 – Valentine’s Day.  The topic – changing last names when marrying.
 
Signing off – Sharon Hessney from Boston, who does what she can to not contribute to climate change, and Amy Ballard from Simpsonville, S.C., who's turning up the heat on climate change awareness.

I noticed that as the decades passed, the temperature was getting higher than before, with temperatures steadily increasing since the 1970s. All years follow a certain pattern in which at the start of January the temperature richest at’s highest point, then drops, and in December it goes back up again. Before 2023, 2016 was the year with the highest temperature, but 2023 surpassed it. 2023 seems to be a weird year, as the temperature stayed comparatively low at the start of the year, and then it steadily increased and reached its highest point in December.

Also, as a Hondurian, the effects of climate change in Honduras are concerning as many cities are flooded more frequently and the heat is worse than before even as a tropical country. 
“Shorter Winters, Hotter Summers, We Are Getting Cooked!”

name: Avonlea Berard
comment info:
1. What do you notice? If your notice makes a claim, where in the graph is the evidence to support it?

I observe that temperatures in the 1940s, 50s, and 60s appear to be fairly consistent, likely contributing to their placement on the same part of the graph. During the 60s and 80s, the data range on the y-axis was predominantly ≤ 0.8. However, in the 70s, 90s, and beyond, the data range consistently exceeded 0.8. Notably, 2016 held the record as the hottest year prior to 2023.

 

2. What do you wonder?

I find it mind-boggling why individuals persist in denying the widespread existence of global warming and climate change, despite clear evidence attributing it, at least in part, if not wholly, to the rise in temperatures over recent decades. I question when governments worldwide will undertake effective measures to address human activities contributing to climate issues, as illustrated in the graph.

 

3. What impact does this have on you and your community?

This pertains to both myself and my community as we observe the tangible impacts of climate change. Winters have become milder than the norm, while summers are increasingly scorching. The temperature shift is palpable globally, impacting communities worldwide.

Let's Ignite Change: It's Time to Amplify Climate Action!

name: A. VanHuysen
comment info:
Relations? 
Looking at this graph from a modern perspective, the response will automatically be global warming. The world is warming, that is a fact. However, what’s causing it? In the 1940s-1970s the temperatures remained fairly constant. But, this was the era of large industrialization, planes and automobiles. For the first time, the average citizen had a car. So, why has the increase in temperature been so significant in modern times? Times that people are so very conscious of carbon emissions? If the argument is that climate change is caused by cars (hence the need for electric cars), then why would an era with such a focus on automobiles have such a low temperature? Were the emissions not happening? Do the emissions accumulate? If they accumulate, then why was the temperature seemingly not impacted by the emissions of the Industrial Revolution? Older cars typically use a carburetor or don’t have a catalytic converter- thus having the potential to use even more gas, and more emissions. So what’s going on here? The earth’s natural cycle? 

Title: 
It’s Gettin’ Hot In Here- The Temperature Results of the Last Century

Good morning, @Landon Harter --

Great observation about the “only” 0.1 degree C. increase.  How did you calculate the 0.1 degree C. increase?  

Remember that the goal of the Paris Agreement is to have less than a 1.5 degree C. increase.  What percentage increase is our increase of the goal?  If not a spike, how would you describe it?  

Also, given what is happening with climate, why not reducing the rate of increase, or having no increase, or having a decline in global temperature?
